;灾难避免了吗？从全球金融市场稳定的狭义角度来看，是的。知道华盛顿众议员普拉米拉贾亚帕尔和马萨诸塞州参议员伊丽莎白沃伦等左翼民主党人几乎肯定会反对乔拜登总统与众议院议长凯文麦卡锡达成的美国债务上限协议，共和党人本可以将美国和全球经济推离通过粘在一起悬崖。

;

;但是他们没有。这是共和党党内战争的一个重要发展，在那些放弃了华盛顿试图在全世界推广的民主价值观的人与那些仍然坚持罗纳德里根的美国和平愿景的人之间。

;

;有人们担心众议院规则委员会中的极右翼共和党人会阻止债务上限法案的通过，在该委员会中，德克萨斯州的奇普罗伊等强硬派获得了席位，以便麦卡锡获得议长的木槌。然而，这些都被夸大了。

;

;该法案在众议院轻松通过。虽然许多投赞成票的共和党人就支出失控发出了可怕的警告，但其中一个抱怨应该给那些支持共和党传统主义者的人带来希望：担心五角大楼将如何支持乌克兰阻止俄罗斯入侵的努力。

;

;“我们现在在世界上有很多麻烦的地区。 Politico 援引科罗拉多州共和党众议员道格·兰博恩的话说，不仅乌克兰，而且中国仍然是我们必须应对的日益严重的威胁。参议院议员、参议院拨款委员会成员、南卡罗来纳州共和党人林赛·格雷厄姆和缅因州拨款委员会高级共和党人苏珊·柯林斯都对北京和莫斯科构成的军事威胁不断上升​​发出警告。

;

;“避免危机”：拜登在椭圆形办公室的首次演讲中庆祝债务上限协议

;

;没有迹象表明共和党人质疑五角大楼对基辅的支持。与俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京一样蔑视进步的西方政策的共和党人可能会意识到他们右翼民粹主义世界的梦想并不那么容易实现。

;

;但共和党人党的内战远未结束。作为参议院共和党人试图通过插入需要在众议院再次投票的修正案来拖延对该法案投票的一部分，路易斯安那州参议员约翰肯尼迪试图插入一项将使食品券接受者的新工作要求永久化的修正案。修正案失败了，其他 10 项修正案也失败了。

;

;“没有工作的人不健康、不快乐、不自由，”肯尼迪说。换句话说，工作让你自由——这一建议让人想起 20 世纪历史上特别可怕的一章。

;

;想知道这样的评论是否是对纳粹主义的眨眼，在修辞上是不可能的前总统唐纳德特朗普支持肯尼迪的连任竞选，他以称白人至上主义者为“非常优秀的人”而闻名，并与大屠杀否认者尼克富恩特斯共进晚餐。

;

;让我们假设肯尼迪从怀疑中受益，并假设他表达了深思熟虑的经济观点。如果是这样的话，我们应该期望他现在会支持进步人士为结束美国税法对资本利得的优惠待遇所做的努力，这是非常富有的人依靠资产产生的被动回报过上舒适生活的方式。

;

;毕竟，没有强有力的证据表明对资本利得的优惠税率会带来更大的创新和经济增长。此外，正如无党派国会研究服务处在 2017 年指出的那样，92.5% 的资本利得和股息税率较低的好处归于收入分配的前五分之一，73% 归于收入分配的前 1 位。

;

;然而，肯尼迪提出的一项拯救闲散富人的法案与他呼吁将骄傲节定为国定假日的可能性一样大。共和党关于工作让我们自由的信息并不适合那些以数百万美元拍卖马格利特和毕加索的人。

;

;但我们不要纠缠于共和党的矛盾或其右翼为拖美国后腿所做的努力到了一个同性恋者躲在壁橱里，女人留在厨房里，少数族裔坐在公共汽车后座的时代。相反，让我们细细品味共和党人愿意与民主党人合作以避免全球灾难的程度。

;

;该党的领导人可能无法让自己说出他希望乌克兰赢得这场战斗这是在反对俄罗斯，强调他对普京等独裁者的亲切感。但是，至少目前，该党似乎正在与这种感染作斗争。

;

;中国周一猛烈抨击欧盟针对北京的贸易措施，声称他们会对世界贸易体系造成“严重影响”。

;

;在日内瓦举行的世界贸易组织 (WTO) 会议上，中国大使李成钢谴责了一系列旨在解决欧洲与中国长期贸易争端的欧盟政策.

;

;他抨击外国补贴法、投资审查和关键的矿产法，称其“不合理且具有歧视性”。据一位日内瓦贸易消息人士称，《欧洲芯片法》也被批评为“扩大出口管制措施”和提高补贴的幌子。

;

;没有任何措施直接提到中国，但它们是为了应对北京的政策而制定的欧盟官员私下承认，WTO 规则无法应对。

;

;这些政策也经过精心设计，以符合 WTO 规则，即使布鲁塞尔预计其中一些政策会在日内瓦贸易中受到挑战

;

;作为这一强有力的新贸易立场的一部分，欧盟官员正准备在本月晚些时候提出一项新的经济安全战略。它将建议限制欧洲对人工智能、半导体和量子计算等敏感高科技领域的部分投资。

;

;同样，该战略预计不会将中国列为目标，但它是首次宣布的在欧盟委员会主席乌尔苏拉·冯德莱恩 3 月份就中国发表的主旨演讲中，该演讲提出了“降低”双边贸易关系风险的计划。

;

;欧盟委员会贸易总干事萨宾·魏安德 (Sabine Weyand)欧盟委员会周一表示，“在当前地缘战略环境中，系统性竞争的不确定性和风险增加”是需要该政策的。

;

;此次交流是在欧盟贸易政策审查会议上进行的，这是一个三年一度的论坛，其他国家世贸组织成员可以表达不满。

;

;中国和其他一些国家对布鲁塞尔的气候政策开枪，包括气候碳边界调整机制 (CBAM)。

;

; CBAM 预计将于 10 月成立，是欧盟寻求到 2050 年实现气候中和的基石。在它全面生效后，想要向欧盟销售商品的公司必须购买反映生产过程中产生的排放量的证书。

;

;据消息人士称，李表示这将不公平地惩罚发展中国家 - 这是南半球普遍存在的抱怨。

;

;欧盟的净零工业法案，未来可能会限制李说，中国向欧盟出口电池、风能和太阳能设备“违反了多边贸易体制的市场原则和基本规则”。

;

;中国寻求世贸组织审查芯片出口限制由美国领导

;

;欧盟的气候政策为在会议期间发言的其他世贸组织成员的官员提供了充足的素材。来自台湾的一名成员敦促布鲁塞尔努力“减轻对 CBAM 的潜在影响和担忧”。

;

;俄罗斯表示，该税将“从根本上挑战全球商品流动的结构和竞争状况

;

;为捍卫欧盟的绿色政策，Weyand 表示，“国内政策制定对于履行《巴黎协定》的承诺至关重要，不采取任何行动是一种选择”，消息人士称。

;

;在不那么激烈的言论中，中国赞扬了“欧盟在维持世贸组织运转方面发挥的重要作用”。两人都是替代上诉法院的成员，该法院在美国阻止任命新法官进入传统上诉机构后不得不成立。

;

;李还赞扬了欧盟为实现“战略自主”所做的努力，这是一个中国官员经常用这个词来形容任何在欧洲和美国之间拉开距离的政策。

;

;华盛顿驻世贸组织特使玛丽亚·帕甘 (María Pagán) 也提供了一份关于欧盟贸易政策的投诉清单，包括其“危害基于法规的方法”——根据接触化学品来限制市场准入——以及使用地理标志来阻止美国葡萄酒出口商在进入欧洲市场时使用“茶色、红宝石和城堡”等术语。

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 01:20:02 +0800 US SEC sues Binance and founder Changpeng Zhao for breaking securities ruleshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3223046/us-sec-sues-binance-and-founder-changpeng-zhao-breaking-securities-rules?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.06 00:32;
;;

;世界上最大的加密货币交易所 Binance 及其首席执行官赵长鹏经营着一个“欺骗网络” ”，美国证券交易委员会周一称，这包括人为夸大其交易量和转移客户资产。

;

;该机构周一起诉 Binance 和 Zhao 未能限制美国客户使用其平台并误导投资者关于其市场监控控制以及经营未注册证券交易所的问题。

;

;美国证券交易委员会向华盛顿联邦法院提起的诉讼还指控币安和赵秘密控制客户的资产，允许他们混合并转移客户资金，并且 Binance 创建了独立的美国实体，“作为逃避美国联邦证券法的精心计划的一部分”。

;

;SEC 还声称，至少从 2019 年 9 月到 2022 年 6 月，Sigma Chain ，一家由 Zhao 拥有和控制的贸易公司，从事虚假交易，人为地夸大 Binance.US 平台上加密货币资产证券的交易量。

;

;“我们声称 Zhao 和 Binance 实体从事广泛的交易SEC 主席加里·金斯勒 (Gary Gensler) 在一份声明中表示：“欺诈、利益冲突、缺乏披露和蓄意逃避法律的网络。”

;

;币安没有立即回应就这些指控发表评论的请求.在一条推文中，Zhao 表示，一旦 Binance 审查了 SEC 的投诉，它将做出回应，并表示该交易所的团队“待命，确保系统稳定，包括提款和存款”。

;

;Binance 的加密货币世界第四大市场规模的 BNB 受此消息影响下跌超过 5%。

;

;此举是 Binance 一系列法律问题中的最新一例，Binance 也被美国商品期货公司起诉交易委员会 (CFTC) 于 3 月因监管机构指控运营“非法”交易所和“虚假”合规计划而被起诉，Zhao 称这些指控“令人失望”且“对事实的陈述不完整”。

;

;据知情人士透露，中国的加密货币之王如何从麦当劳变成亿万富翁

;

;Binance 也因涉嫌洗钱和违反制裁规定而受到司法部的调查。

;

;作为全球最大的加密货币交易所，币安于 2017 年由首席执行官赵长鹏在上海创立，赵长鹏是加拿大公民，在中国出生并成长到 12 岁。

;

;虽然其控股公司位于开曼群岛，但币安表示它没有总部，并拒绝透露其主要 Binance.com 交易所的位置。

;

;Binance 的全球交易平台 Binance.com 在加密货币交易领域占据主导地位，去年处理的交易价值约为 10 亿美元每天 650 亿美元，占据高达 70% 的市场份额。

;

;据路透社此前报道，该公司已为寻求逃避美国制裁的犯罪分子和公司处理了至少 100 亿美元的付款。

;

;路透社 5 月 23 日还报道称，币安将其客户的资金与其公司收入混合在属于贸易公司 Merit Peak 的 Silvergate 银行账户中，这违反了要求客户资金分开存放的美国金融规则。

;

;Binance 否认将客户存款和公司资金混在一起，称向该账户汇款的用户并未存款，而是购买了 Binance 定制的与美元挂钩的加密货币代币。

;香港在重建其作为航空枢纽的角色方面面临着“艰巨而具有挑战性”的任务一家全球航空公司协会的负责人表示，到今年年底，该市的旗舰航空公司国泰航空公司的运力预计将仅为大流行前的 60%。

;

;但是国际航空运输协会 (IATA) 总干事威利沃尔什周一在伊斯坦布尔举行的年度会议上表示，整个行业的前景是积极的，预计今年全球利润将达到 98 亿美元，是 12 月份预测的两倍，

;

;Walsh 去年 12 月告诉邮报，他预计香港在 2028 年之前不会完全恢复其作为航空枢纽的地位，并指出该城市将在 2028 年之前发生“结构性变化”三年的 Covid-19 旅行限制。

;

;当再次被问及他之前的评论时，Walsh 承认他的时间表是基于对香港与竞争对手相比在复苏过程中所处位置的“感觉”。

;

;“它正在重建，但我认为它已经失去了很多阵地，而且失去的阵地需要时间才能恢复，”他说，并补充说这将是“非常困难和具有挑战性的任务” .

;

;Walsh 认为，国泰航空在重建其国际网络方面面临着一个复杂的过程。

;

;“我认为国泰航空今年将以 60% 的产能运营，因为他们对飞行员进行了再培训，其中许多他说：“他们在过去两年内没有飞行过，”他说。

;

;国泰航空及其预算子公司香港快运航空设定了到今年年底达到大流行前客运量的 70% 的目标到 2024 年底将达到 100%。

;

;国泰廉价航空公司香港快运航空的航班“在周五前恢复到 Covid 之前的水平”

;

;香港解除了 Covid-19 对国际航班的限制去年 12 月抵达香港，并于 2 月恢复了与中国大陆的免检疫旅行。

;

;独立航空分析师 Brendan Sobie 表示，在将航空业恢复到 2019 年的水平方面，香港比新加坡等其他地方落后一年。

;

;他说，由于地勤人员短缺，外国航空公司在增加香港国际机场服务方面面临挑战，但他补充说，“随着时间的推移”，这个问题会得到解决。

;

;“仍然存在一些挥之不去的问题，但比以前好多了，”Sobie 说。 “对于希望增加香港运力但未能做到的航空公司来说，这是一个渐进的过程。”

;

;国际航空运输协会周一表示，全球航空业预计将在香港赚取 98 亿美元2023年实现净利润，总收入预计同比增长9.7%至8030亿美元。该组织表示，目前估计去年行业净亏损为 36 亿美元。

;

;在夏季到来之前，新加坡航空公司和阿联酋航空等航空公司的利润创下历史新高。

;

;香港国泰航空任命林郑月娥为首席执行官，以建设产能

;

;据该行业机构称，预计 2023 年将有约 43.5 亿人出行，约为 2019 年出行人数的 95%。

;

;据香港旅行社称，被压抑的飞行需求使机票价格比大流行前高出 15% 至 40%。

;

;但航班供应也受到飞机交付延误和恢复停放飞机的复杂过程、油价上涨和人员短缺的影响。

;

;IATA 首席经济学家 Marie Owens Thomsen 说她“惊讶”乘客没有

;

;“从逻辑上讲，你会认为这不会永远持续下去，在某个时候，乘客会对价格更加敏感，”她说。

;

;Thomsen 补充说，高通胀和失业率上升等经济不确定性可能会对未来产生影响。

;

;中国大陆是全球航空业复苏的重要组成部分。 2019 年，大陆旅客出境游超过 1.5 亿人次，消费约 1 万亿美元。

;

;今年前三个月，往返中国的航班载客量约 220 万人次，占全国的 12.4%根据中国民用航空总局的数据，这是 2019 年第一季度冠状病毒爆发前的数字。

;

;Thomsen 表示，中国旅游市场的复苏形式仍存在疑问，并指出从大陆出发的国际航班仍处于“非常低的水平”。

;

;由于缺乏航班选择，大多数中国大陆人通过香港飞往海外：IATA

;

;各国正在增加飞往中国的航班，但美国是“明显的例外”，汤姆森称这是由于地缘政治因素。

;

;周日，国际航空运输协会北亚区副主席谢兴权表示，航空公司在中国和美国之间运营着 24 个航班谢说，美国每周都有，仅占 2019 年水平的 6%。

;

;虽然存在对更多航班的需求，但双边谈判中的“困难”使得增加航班数量成为一项挑战。< /p>;

;

;采购经理人指数 (PMI) 是从月度调查中得出的经济指标。它们每个月都提供制造业和服务业经济活动的早期迹象。服务业包括建筑业。

;

;与上月相比，高于 50 的读数代表扩张，低于 50 的读数代表收缩。读数为 50 表示没有变化。

;

;那么，最近的数据说明了世界第二大经济体的状况如何？

;

;

;

;中国官方制造业采购经理人指数 (PMI) 从 4 月份的 49.2 降至 5 月份的 48.8。

;

;5 月份的读数是该指数自 12 月份降至 47 以来的最低水平。

;

;在官方制造业采购经理人指数显示，新订单分项指数从 4 月份的 48.8 降至 5 月份的 48.3，而新出口订单分项指数从 47.6 降至 47.2。

;

;与从 56.4 跌至 54.5 的非制造业指数相比，制造业 PMI“表明服务业和制造业之间的复苏存在持续分歧”。

;

;“令人失望的 5 月国家统计局 PMI 显示复苏迹象势头继续消退。尽管政策制定者重申了支持增长的立场，但还需要做更多工作来帮助增强家庭和企业的信心，并使增长复苏重回正轨，”大中华区经济学家 Erin Xin 和 Jing Liu 表示。

;

;与此同时，财新/标准普尔全球制造业采购经理人指数 (PMI) 从 4 月份的 49.5 升至 50.9。

;

;国泰君安国际经济学家周浩表示，读数是“中国经济的好消息”，但需要更多时间来确定这种改善能否持续。

;

;需求是中国工厂面临“螺旋式下降”的“罪魁祸首”

;

;财新 PMI 被认为侧重于沿海地区更多以出口为导向的小型企业，由标准普尔全球根据对中国采购经理人的问卷调查的答复编制而成。

;

;但是虽然财新中国的采购经理人指数以及日本的一项类似调查显示，上个月工厂活动向增长方向摆动，这与韩国、越南和台湾的疲弱指标形成鲜明对比，由于全球需求低迷仍然是许多人面临的主要挑战，因此这些指标持续下滑亚洲主要出口商。

;

;

;

;中国官方非制造业采购经理人指数 (PMI) 从 4 月份的 56.4 降至 5 月份的 54.5。

;

;在官方非制造业PMI，服务业指数从55.1下降至53.8，而建筑业指数也从63.9降至四个月低点58.2。

;

;凯投宏观分析师表示，建筑业指数回落表明“今年前期财政支持对基础设施支出的支持现在开始消退”。

;

;野村分析师表示，韧性非制造业采购经理人指数“主要受到一连串的支持”在疫情后的第一个“黄金周”假期期间，旅游和聚会的需求受到抑制。

;

;国内旅游收入已跃升至大流行前水平的 101%，达到 1480 亿元人民币（209 亿美元），在 4 月底至 5 月初的五天假期期间。

;

;与此同时，财新/标准普尔全球服务业采购经理人指数 (PMI) 从 4 月份的 56.4 升至 5 月份的 57.1。

;< h3>;随着订单支撑消费带动的复苏，中国服务业活动回升;

;调查显示，由于五一假期提振了酒店、餐馆和旅行社的订单，服务公司报告的新业务有所增加。;

; p>;

;财新智库高级经济学家王哲表示，“服务业强于制造业仍是中国经济的突出特点”。

;

;

;

;中国将于周三公布 5 月份的贸易数据，周五将公布上个月的通胀数据。

;

;北京已承诺支持贸易以支持整体经济复苏，但中国的出口因疲软而举步维艰全球需求。

;

;中国的经济复苏已经受到青年失业率上升以及令人失望的零售销售和工业生产的打击。

;

;这促使一些国际投资银行削减了他们的全部 -

;

;但 Capital Economics 的分析师 Julian Evans-Pritchard 表示，在制造业产出之后，中国第二季度的国内生产总值 (GDP) 增长“可能没有许多人担心的那么糟糕”

;

;“PMI 调查表明，5 月份中国经济仍在持续复苏。财政支持的减弱打压了建筑活动。但制造业产出略有上升，服务业仍有可观的增长，”Evans-Pritchard 表示。

;

;“财新综合采购经理人指数在 5 月份升至 2020 年 12 月以来的最高水平，这要归功于经济增长的改善服务业。官方采购经理人指数不那么乐观。但总的来说，该数据与上个月经济活动的更快增长是一致的。

;

;“目前，综合 PMI 表明官方 [GDP] 环比增长约 2.5%，本季度 (假设 6 月没有变化）。这高于我们预测的第二季度 1.8% 的季度环比增长率，这让我们对今年 6.5% 的高于市场普遍预期的 [国内生产总值] 预测感到满意。”

; Mon, 05 Jun 2023 23:50:02 +0800 Detroit, host city of recent Apec meetings, embodies Joe Biden’s trade policy goal of renewalhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3222994/detroit-host-city-recent-apec-meetings-embodies-joe-bidens-trade-policy-goal-renewal?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.05 23:00;
;;

;When Detroit filed for bankruptcy in 2013, many news outlets used the ruins of Michigan Central Station as an illustration of the city's long, slow collapse. Last month, less than two miles from the 20th century rail junction, US President Joe Biden's top trade official hosted counterparts from 21 Asia-Pacific economies to pitch a new vision of American trade policy.

;

;“Detroit has experienced first-hand some of the most negative impacts of an aggressive liberalisation of trade and de-industrialisation”, US Trade Representative Katherine Tai said in her opening remarks at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) trade ministers' meetings, held on May 25-26.

;

;She mentioned “factories that have shuttered and communities who have suffered” in aligning her remarks with Biden's approach to industrial policy. His goal is for the federal government to play an active role in the revival of domestic manufacturing, reshaping supply chains, creating local jobs and fighting climate change instead of pursuing free trade deals.

;

;It was on the streets of Detroit in the late 1800s where Henry Ford, the founder of Ford Motors, drove his first car. A few decades into the 20th century, more than 100 automobile manufacturing companies, including General Motors and Chrysler, had sprung up, giving the city its “Motor City” moniker. Between 1940-1947, Detroit became home to the country's highest paid blue collar workers and boasted a population of 1.85 million.

;

;Despite being hailed as a success story of American capitalism and modern consumerism, signs of Detroit's downfall began in the early 1950s as the auto industry started relocating manufacturing units in pursuit of cheaper land and workers. In the next decade, many of the 20th century factories and residential neighbourhoods were emptied and abandoned. Competition from foreign manufacturers, especially in Japan and Germany, led to shrinking market shares.

;

;By 1980, the city's population had plummeted by 35 per cent from its peak in 1950 as more manufacturing jobs were lost. For the past 30 years, the population decline has continued. According to the 2020 census, Detroit has been reduced to 632,464 residents.

;

;But the winds of change are blowing again. Michigan Central Station, which was closed in 1988, now represents the future of trade policy that is hinged on the renewal of American manufacturing.

;

;The 30-acre passenger rail depot was acquired by Ford in 2018 and is being transformed into an electric vehicle innovation hub in collaboration with Google. The project is estimated to cost about US$700 million and create more than 2,500 jobs. “Just a few years ago, this train station was our city's international symbol of abandonment,” Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan said last year. “Now it's the symbol of our city's resurgence.”

;

;Apec: China's commerce minister condemns chip controls and 'smears' at G7

;

;Both American automobile companies and Detroit officials are betting big on Biden's mission to have at least 50 per cent of new US vehicles be electric by 2030. The US$135 billion federal investment to realise that goal is tied to bringing offshore manufacturing and good-paying jobs back to the US as it competes for technological and economic supremacy against China, the world's second largest economy and a global leader in the EV market.

;

;Last July, General Motors said it was setting up “Factory Zero” in Detroit to expand its EV production capacity. In February, Ford announced plans to build a US$3.5 billion plant near the city to make lower-cost batteries for electric vehicles.

;

;Anticipating an EV boom, the city administration is planning to make Detroit “the leader in the Midwest for charging infrastructure”, said Tim Slusser, Detroit's chief of mobility innovation, emphasising that these efforts will drive new economic opportunities.

;

;“We have been, for the last 100 years, the home of the automotive industry. We're now embracing what the next 100 years is going to look like,” he added.

;

;Tai shared that sentiment with Apec trade ministers. “This meeting is an opportunity to recognise and honour the generations of working people right up to this present day, who have made Detroit an engine of the US economy,” she told them, adding that it would not be an exaggeration to say that Detroit's “past, present and future is at the heart” of Biden's worker-centric trade policy.

;

;Addressing trade ministers and officials from Apec countries, including New Zealand, Chile, Japan and Canada, at an event hosted by Tai, Frederick Redmond, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, condemned free trade deals for having a “disproportionately negative” impact on workers and decimating the US' industrial manufacturing base.

;

;“We are honoured to be here because we have the opportunity to reverse the damage to trade policies with workers at the centre. That's what this is about,” he said.

;

;Said Tai as she shared the stage with Redmond: “What has been missed in all of this conversation is the fact that every consumer is also a worker, a wage earner … in order to consume, you also got to have a good job.”

;

;Tai's enthusiasm for Detroit and Biden's efforts to bring jobs back to the US more broadly represent a break from the recent history of the administration's Democratic Party and has yet to fully align with the partners that she seeks to build ties with.

;

;Their attempt to portray Detroit as symbolic of future US trade policy runs counter to the last bloc meeting hosted by the US, in 2011 during president Barack Obama's administration. That forum was held in Big Sky, Montana to explore “limitless possibilities”, according to a USTR press release, and to support jobs through exports while increasing cooperation and economic integration across the Asia-Pacific though trade deals.

;

;In contrast to Biden's approach, however, many small and developing Apec member economies are looking for greater access to free markets and reduced costs. This poses a challenge for his team trying to sell his vision to regional partners, many of whom are also part of multilateral trade agreements like the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).

;

;Both agreements offer free-market access and reduced tariffs.

;

;In 2017, Biden's predecessor, Donald Trump, withdrew the US from the 12-member Trans-Pacific Partnership, the CPTPP's predecessor, saying the move would protect domestic manufacturing and its workers. The initial deal was signed during the Obama administration to counter China's rise.

;

;The CPTPP agreement currently includes Canada, Mexico, Peru, Chile, New Zealand, Australia, Brunei, Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam and Japan Together the signatories' economies account for 10 per cent of the global GDP.

;

;Biden, who took office in 2021, has ruled out rejoining the group, while China has applied for membership. Beijing is also a member of the RCEP, whose ranks include US allies like Japan and South Korea.

;

;Ironically, the city the Biden administration had expected to help further its new trade agenda also became the venue, on the Apec sidelines, for 11 CPTPP member nations to discuss the deepening of trade ties and the bloc's expansion. The US was obviously absent.

;

;“It's openly known that we'd all welcome the US at any time that it chooses to come back in,” said New Zealand Trade Minister Damien O'Connor. According to reports, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has also asked Washington to return to the trade deal.

;

;Amid Micron ban, US working with allies to beat China's 'economic coercion'

;

;Non-alignment of the Biden's vision with allies and partners was also visible at the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework ministerial meeting held in Detroit on May 27. The US launched the economic initiative last year to counter China's influence in the region.

;

;And though the 13 participating countries, led by the US, reached a consensus on building sustainable and resilient supply chains focused on critical minerals and semiconductors, divergence over trade remained.

;

;India, a key regional ally to the US, did not participate in trade talks. The government of Narendra Modi has faced pressure at home to withdraw from the IPEF trade negotiations.

;

;Tai stressed that the US was pursuing different goals. “We're not just trying to maximise efficiencies and liberalisation,” she said, adding that the purpose was to “promote sustainability, resilience and inclusiveness”.

;

;As overlapping blocs met on the Apec sidelines in Detroit, the road to American leadership in global trade policy looked bumpy. As outlined by US national security adviser Jake Sullivan the previous month, the Biden administration views traditional trade deals as a “project of the 1990s” that are different from the “project of the 2020s and 2030s”.

;

;“In today's world, trade policy needs to be about more than tariff reduction,” he said. But many US allies and partners still believe in the traditional model and seem reluctant to fully adopt US's “new approach”, at least for now.

;China has proposed the establishment of a unified domestic market amid efforts to offset the impact of external factors, including weak overseas demand, financial volatility and sanction threats, which threaten the overall economic recovery amid weak market sentiment.

;

;But what is the progress of a plan that was first mentioned in 2013 before Beijing stepped up its efforts last year?

;

;

;

;The concept of a unified domestic market was first officially proposed in a top-level 2013 reform document, which focused on removing regional protectionism and encouraging competition.

;

;But in April 2022, Beijing released guidelines on accelerating the establishment of a unified domestic market.

;

;China speeds up inward economic push with plan for 'unified domestic market'

;

;The unified domestic market is intended to enable a more efficient and smooth flow of production factors, including labour, goods, capital and data.

;

;The guidelines are regarded as a foundation to prop up President Xi Jinping's new development outlook, which focuses on the quality of economic growth, more secure development and increased innovation.

;

;

;

;China is already the world's largest consumer goods market, with spending on consumer goods and catering reaching 44 trillion yuan (US$6.2 trillion) in 2022.

;

;It is also the world's top buyer of iron ore, crude oil and industrial metals.

;

;The move to establish a unified domestic market is widely believed to be a response to fast changing domestic and international environments.

;

;Externally, the move is a way to deal with the US trade war and ongoing decoupling endeavours, as China has to consume more when overseas demand is shrinking amid high tariffs and disruptions caused by the coronavirus.

;

;What is China's dual circulation strategy and why is it important?

;

;This was highlighted in May 2020 as Beijing released its dual circulation strategy.

;

;The strategy places a greater focus on the domestic market, or internal circulation, while placing less reliance on its export-oriented development strategy, or external circulation, but without abandoning it altogether.

;

;A unified domestic market is also a way to keep foreign investors onshore, as its market of 1.4 billion potential consumers, including around 400 million people in the middle class group, represent huge business opportunities.

;

;China is also experiencing a steady decline of orders from the United States, while foreign direct investment fell by 3.3 per cent year on year in the first four months of 2023.

;

;

;

;The primary task of last year's guidelines are to encourage competition, lower institutional costs, boost efficiency and productivity, elevate tech innovation and promote international cooperation.

;

;All of the tasks are vital for China's 2035 growth target of doubling its gross domestic product from 2020 levels.

;

;Specifically, the government campaign includes plans to implement unified market access standards, fair competition, a social credit system, intellectual property rights protection and the free flow of labour and data.

;

;

;

;Foreign businesses and private companies have long been complaining about varying enforcement of regulatory standards and different entry barriers in China.

;

;This is especially true because state-owned enterprises are often seen to enjoy hidden advantages in government procurement, bank lending and bidding.

;

;In its annual position paper released at the end of May, the British Chamber of Commerce in China flagged uneven local enforcement in areas including customs clearance waiting time and new data security law.

;

;“For businesses as a whole, enforcement of laws and regulations were the fourth most cited challenge for member companies,” the chamber said.

;

;“[China needs to] ensure uniform enforcement of laws and regulations across different provinces and cities.”

;

;According to research by Wu Qunfeng, an academic at Peking University's School of Economics, a commodity will be taxed by an additional 3. 8 to 19. 6 per cent when it crosses different provincial borders.

;

;Companies also have to face the impact of a less circulated labour force under China's hukou system, which allocates public services to citizens based on their place of birth.

;

;This means increased costs for companies considering bringing in talent from other provinces.

;

;

;

;It is widely viewed as a long-term plan, and while some of the tasks have started, progress has been slow.

;

;China's top economic planner, the National Development and Reform Commission, launched a public consultation on the reform of the social credit system at the end of last year, saying it would help optimise the business environment.

;

;China to expand rural access to urban welfare benefits in push for growth

;

;China has largely lifted hukou restrictions, while tier-one cities such as Shanghai and Beijing have eased curbs on the settlement of talent and introduced more public service for migrant workers.

;

;China's cabinet, the State Council, said in mid-May that it will implement a new appraisal and incentive system for officials.

;

;Previously, officials preferred to favour local enterprises in order to obtain promotion, which has long led to the prevalence of local protectionism.

;Nvidia's billionaire founder and chief executive Jensen Huang Jen-hsun has left Taiwan to return to the United States, skipping a reported planned trip to mainland China, according to media reports.

;

;Huang, 60, returned to the US after completing a trip to Taiwan last week, the Beijing-based Economic Observer reported, citing a company representative.

;

;The official Shanghai Securities News reported last week that Huang was expected to arrive in Shanghai on Tuesday, echoing an earlier report by Bloomberg News that Huang planned to meet executives from Tencent Holdings, TikTok owner ByteDance, smartphone giant Xiaomi, and automobile makers BYD and Li Auto this month in China.

;

;Nvidia, the world's most valuable chip maker, has never confirmed or published any information about Huang's planned trip to mainland China. The company did not immediately respond to a request for comment by the Post on Monday.

;

;Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said to arrive in Shanghai on Tuesday

;

;The move is likely to upset mainland fans, as a visit to mainland China by Huang would have been seen as a sign that the country is too big a market to ignore. As the current US-China tech war rolls on, the Taiwan-born American entrepreneur told reporters last month at a round table at Computex Taipei, an annual technology industry expo, that China's ability to catch up in chip technology should not be underrated.

;

;Under the updated US export control regime, Nvidia is unable to sell its most advanced chips to China where demand for such chips is enormous.

;

;Huang, who founded Nvidia in 1993, has been vocal about the impact of Washington's sanctions on China's access to semiconductors. To comply with Washington's rules, Nvidia has to offer lower-end versions of its most advanced graphics processing units (GPUs) that are tailor-made for the mainland market.

;

;Huang has been in the media spotlight for several days in Taiwan, where he received a rock star welcome. He kicked off hi tour on May 27 at the National Taiwan University in Taipei, where he encouraged graduating students in a commencement address to “run hard” and seize the “golden opportunities” of an AI revolution.

;

;Huang unveiled a series of new products and services related to AI at Computex Taipei. Speaking at the trade fair, he noted that China is pouring massive resources into shoring up its chip sector.

;

;In an interview with the Financial Times last month, he was quoted as saying the Biden administration should be “careful” with its semiconductor restrictions, because “if [China] can't buy from … the United States, they'll just build it themselves”.

;

;During his whirlwind trip to Taiwan, he also had dinner with Morris Chang, founder of the world's largest chip foundry Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, which builds Nvidia's flagship chips, such as the H100.

;The UN on Monday said it was alarmed over Hong Kong detentions of people who tried to mark the 34th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown at the weekend.

;

;But the Chinese Foreign Ministry dismissed the criticism and said it was an attempt to “smear China and interfere in its internal affairs” which would not succeed.

;

;The war of words broke out after police detained a total of 32 people over the weekend in connection with the June 4 anniversary – eight on Saturday and 24 on Sunday.

;

;There were five arrests and others, including journalist Mak Yin-ting, were detained but later released.

;

;The office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said: “We are alarmed by reports of detentions linked to the June 4 anniversary.”

;

;“We urged the release of anyone detained for exercising freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. We call on authorities to fully abide by obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.”

;

;Wang Wenbin, the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman hours later told a regular news conference that China's government had “long come to a clear conclusion regarding the political turmoil that occurred in the late 1980s”.

;

;“I also want to emphasise that any attempt to use this as an excuse to smear China and interfere in its internal affairs will not succeed,” Wang added.

;

;He added that Beijing supported the city authorities in their efforts to maintain security and stability.

;

;Wang was speaking after China's foreign ministry commissioner in the city issued a statement “strongly rejecting and deploring” commemorations by foreign consulates as a “self-humiliating political farce”.

;

;A spokesman for the commissioner highlighted the consulates general of the United States and Canada.

;

;“By hyping up an event that has long come to a conclusion, a small number of external forces are obsessed with acting as clowns to throw dirty water on China, put a spoke in the wheel of Hong Kong's development, and incite antagonism and confrontation”. he said.

;

;“Those who play this trick are just overestimating their own strength and their plots will be consigned to the dustbin of history.”

;

;The consulates of Britain, Australia and the European Union office also posted commemorative images or messages on social media on Sunday.

;

;The Canadian consulate's message said that it joined Hongkongers and others around the world in “remembering the violent crackdown against unarmed and peaceful citizens” on June 4, 1989.

;

;A spokesman for the Chief Executive's Office said on Monday it would not comment on the actions of the consulates.

;

;But a Security Bureau spokesman rejected the UN and journalists' association views as “fact-twisting and unfounded”.

;

;“The government law enforcement agencies will continue to enforce the laws without fear or favour to safeguard national security and social order,” he said.

;

;The bureau maintained the city residents' freedoms and rights were guaranteed by the Basic Law, the city's mini-constitution.

;

;The bureau also highlighted that the international covenant on human and civil rights included exemptions “necessary for protection of national security, public safety, public order or the rights and freedoms of others”.

;

;Thousands of police officers to patrol Hong Kong on Tiananmen Square anniversary

;

;Police arrested five people in the area of Causeway Bay's Victoria Park on Saturday and Sunday. They were released on bail on Monday, but ordered to report back to police in early July.

;

;Most were detained for alleged “acts with a seditious intention” and for “behaving in a disorderly manner in a public place”.

;

;The police also arrested a 53-year-old woman on Sunday night in Victoria Park for alleged obstruction of police officers.

;

;The Hong Kong Journalist Association said on Monday that Mak was reporting for Radio France Internationale in Causeway Bay when she was stopped by police around 6pm on Sunday.

;

;She was later taken to Wan Chai police station where she was detained until 11pm, then freed without charge.

;

;“We urge the police to respect the rights of journalists to carry out their reporting duties and not to arbitrarily detain them, which seriously obstructs their work. We request that the police explain this incident,” the association said.

;

;The association added Mak had shown her media credentials to officers when she was first stopped but was told she would still be searched.

;

;Hong Kong's Tiananmen vigil: police close down part of Victoria Park

;

;There were also reports that officers confiscated a black painting of a candle at a store in Sai Kung on Sunday.

;

;A private car with the licence number “US8964” was impounded in Causeway Bay and a Yuen Long lamp post with the number “FA 8964” was also cordoned off.

;

;Hong Kong's opposition Democratic Party said the actions taken by the authorities had gone too far and could fuel social conflicts.

;

;“The government's excessive sensitivity towards a so-called 'sensitive day' not only disturbs the public but also fails to mend societal divisions,” Chan Po-ming, the party's spokesman for economic and fiscal policy, said.

;

;“Instead, it may cause residents to worry about the implementation of one country, two systems and the protection of their rights under the Basic Law.”

;

;But Professor Lau Siu-kai, just appointed as an adviser on government policy, said the police's high profile actions acted as a deterrent to people who might think of chancing their luck with protests.

;

;“You may see it as a preventive self-defence tactic,” Lau, also a consultant at Beijing's semi-official think tank the Chinese Association of Hong Kong and Macau Studies, explained.

;

;Hong Kong, once the only place on Chinese soil that large scale June 4 commemorations were allowed, has not had its landmark June 4 vigil at Victoria Park since 2019.

;

;The event was organised by the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China, which disbanded in 2021 and attracted tens of thousands of people.

;

;But the authorities refused to grant approval for the event in 2020 and 2021 because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

;

;No other organisations stepped up to organise a vigil in 2022 or this year.
